article.title: A new lower bound for the on-line coloring of intervals with bandwidth

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following statements is **TRUE** about the intervals marked with a \'*\' in Figure 1?
choices: They represent intervals introduced in the (i+1)-th subphase.
They are not necessarily marked in the (i-1)-th subphase.
They must have been assigned the same color by the Algorithm.
They all have their right endpoints to the left of *li-1*.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 2, what does the distance between *Pi-1* and *Ri-1* represent?
choices: The length *si-1* of intervals introduced in the (i-1)-th subphase.
The bandwidth of intervals introduced in the (i-1)-th subphase.
The number of marked intervals in *Mi-1*.
The total number of colors used by the Algorithm after (i-1)-th subphase.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Equation (1) guarantee when satisfied by a k-strategy Sk?
choices: The k-strategy Sk will remain a k-strategy even after scaling.
The Algorithm will be forced to use at least zkxi new colors in each subphase.
The scaled version of Sk will also be a valid strategy for a larger problem.
The total number of colors used by the Algorithm will be minimized.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the values in the *Î“i* row in Table 2?
choices: They represent the bandwidth of intervals introduced in the corresponding subphase.
They indicate the maximum number of new colors Algorithm can be forced to use in that subphase.
They represent the number of colors used by the Presenter to color all marked intervals up to that subphase.
They denote the number of non-marked intervals after each subphase.
